common.text:
Ancient texts

Due to the frequent confusion with the literal interpretation of the Mesopotamian flood, we wrote a serie of four texts to help readers to undertstand what ancient authors were describing:

  • (Texts with Sciences (Part I)): we study the concepts of "world" and "sky" in Mesopotamian cultures and how the lack of understanding of the surrounding environment may have led to the idea of an extraordinarily long lifespan, incompatible with human nature.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Part II)): we explore the water cycle and the law of conservation of mass. With this, we discussed how the concept of "world" in Mesopotamia differs from our own.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Part III)): we examined the epics of *Gilgamesh* and *Atrahasis*, as well as the Sumerian deluge narratives. Within them, we identified a recurring narrative pattern: a few people and animals are saved in a boat, described in various shapes (cubic or circular), following a divine punishment. From this, we established the probable periods in which these deluges occurred and compared them with data from other regions, concluding that there were no global floods.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Conclusion)): we concluded our study with an analysis of two different papers that mapped floods across the world at various times, providing context for the conditions under which Mediterranean authors wrote their texts.
Figura 2: Sumerian King List. Â© Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford (Ashmolean Image Library).

maps.text: Part of map of Asia highlighting the region from Mesopotamia to the Zagros Mountains in Iran, representing the areas occupied by the ancient Sumerians (Kessler, P. L., ). The area is marked approximately to provide the reader with a clearer visualization

history.text: This city in the list of kings begins to include historically recognized figures, such as Enmebagaresi (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, Kish, ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, Enmebaragesi, ; History with Cy, 06:32, ). However, there are still records of reigns with durations impossible for human beings, as discussed in the introduction
We can't help but highlight the "precision" of the duration attributed to this king's reign: he ruled for (?) 420 years ...., 3 months, and 3 1/2 days

Before Atab/Aba, the translation of the Sumerian king list informs us: "the 10th and 11th rulers of the dynasty preceded the 8th and 9th" (Black, J.A. et. all, ). This is the first instance in the list where we observe a relationship between fathers and sons, suggesting the establishment of a dynasty
According to the list of kings
According to the list of kings
In this section, we explore the mythological figure Etana, the shepherd, who is described as: "who ascended to heaven and consolidated all the foreign countries"

In addition to being mentioned in the *List of Kings*, Etana is also the central figure in an epic that bears his name. Although the epic has survived only in fragments, it is accessible through the Electronic Babylonian Library and World History Encyclopedia
According to the List of Kings
In this fourth part we have the En-me-nuna's family
According to the List of Kings

According to the List of Kings (Black, J.A. et. all, ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

This relationship is considered hypothetical because, in the List of Kings where Barsal-nuna is mentioned, there is an earlier reference stating: 1560 are the years of the dynasty of En-me-nuna (Black, J.A. et. all, ; Black, J.A. et. all, ). However, the combined reigns of En-me-nuna and his supposed brother exceed this period, suggesting a possible error or the existence of a homonym
According to the List of Kings
According to the List of Kings

This is the last group of kings on this page for which there is no physical evidence of their existence, aside from ancient texts. In other words, this is the final section covering the mythological figures of the First Dynasty of Kish.

Are texts considered primary sources? This is a question that requires further exploration. Documents that have survived to the present day are considered primary sources and can help confirm the existence of historical figures. However, the further back we go in time, the more we encounter a blend of history and belief within these texts. We understand that a person truly existed when, in addition to textual references â often recorded centuries or even millennia after the personâs supposed lifetime â there is also physical evidence, such as artifacts, to support those mentions.

Can oral tradition preserve names for centuries? This is a commonly raised argument, which leads to the following reflection:

Reflection 2: The Limits of Oral Tradition

Is oral tradition enough to confirm the historical existence of a person? Or is it more of a collective belief, not necessarily supported by concrete evidence?
Would you accept oral traditions that contradict your own beliefs?

In concluding the analysis of the early kings of Kish, we encounter the dynasty of Enmebaragesi, the first king whose existence has been confirmed by archaeological evidence (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, Kish, ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, Enmebaragesi, ; History with Cy, 06:32, )
His existence is confirmed by a vase inscription: "me-bara2-si lugal kisz"
Figure 4: Vase inscription proving the historicity of King Enmebaragesi.
Enmebaragesi ruled by 900 years and conquered the Elam region

Aga, son of Enmebaragesi, is also listed in the Sumerian King List. He reportedly ruled for 625 years (Black, J.A. et. all, ; Black, J.A. et. all, ). Aga is also mentioned in the Sumerian poem Gilgamesh and Aga, which recounts a meeting between Aga and Gilgamesh, the king of Uruk (Black, J.A. et. all, ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

This literary reference leads us to the following reflection:

?
Floods in the Ancient Middle East

The Epic of Gilgamesh describes a great flood, and considering that Gilgamesh lived during the same period as Aga, it is possible that this flood does not correspond to the one mentioned earlier in the Sumerian King List. This is because Aga began his reign approximately 23,885 years after the flood recorded at the beginning of the list (Gilgamesh epic ; Mark, J. J., Gilgamesh, ). However, if we consider only the reigns of Enmebaragesiâhistorically the first verified kingâand his son, the time gap between these events reduces significantly.
How many floods might have occurred in the ancient Mediterranean world?

Samuel Noah Kramer noted that floods in the Middle East were not uncommon. For example, in , the Tigris River "submerged the low-lying plain for hundreds of miles" (Kramer, Samuel Noah, ). Kramer concluded that the flood described in ancient texts likely had its origins in a real catastrophic event, though it was not a universal event.

exercise_v2.question: Has the historical existence of all the kings listed in the Sumerian King List been proven?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: With the exception of the last two kings, the lack of information about the other kings suggest they are mythological figures.

exercise_v2.question: Did the floods that occurred in the Mediterranean region flood the entire world?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The understanding of the world millennia ago was very different from what we have today. Many peoples, for example, believed that the Earth was flat, a conception that has been debunked for centuries and is now widely illustrated by images from space (Hu, X., Shum, C.K. & Bevis, M, ; , Earth 3D Model. NASA ; Hossenfelder, Sabine, ). Thus, when reporting events, ancient peoples considered the "world" as the nearby horizon they knew. With this idea, they could not have been referring to global scales as we understand them today.
